Source: Gwiazdowska D, Czaczyk K, Filipiak M, Gwiazdowski R. Effects of Propionibacterium on the growth and mycotoxin production by some species of Fusarium and Alternaria. Pol J Microbiol. 2008;57(3):205-12. PMID: 19004241.
Additional information: NA
Curation notes: Three experimental preparations of viable bacteria, cell free supernatant and bacterionin prep were analyzed in their ability to remove or decrease levels of mycotoxin. The strongest inhibition of growth and toxin production was observed in the presence of cultures containing viable cells and supernatants obtained from propionibacteria cultures.

Source: Farzaneh M, Shi ZQ, Ahmadzadeh M, Hu LB, Ghassempour A. Inhibition of the Aspergillus flavus Growth and Aflatoxin B1 Contamination on Pistachio Nut by Fengycin and Surfactin-Producing Bacillus subtilis UTBSP1. Plant Pathol J. 2016 Jun;32(3):209-15. doi: 10.5423/PPJ.OA.11.2015.0250. Epub 2016 Jun 1. PMID: 27298596; PMCID: PMC4892817.
Additional information: NA
Curation notes: The enzyme responsible for the B subtilis strain UTBSP1-caused decrease in Aflotoxin mycotoxin is an extracellular constituively produced enzyme. When preparations UTBSP1 were analyzed in nutrient broth culture, in the pistachio nut and cel-free supernatant, it was found that cell-free supernatant had an efficacy rate of 78.39% decrease in AFB1 content while the other two preparations had 86% and 95% decreases.

Source: Wang J, Ogata M, Hirai H, Kawagishi H. Detoxification of aflatoxin B1 by manganese peroxidase from the white-rot fungus Phanerochaete sordida YK-624. FEMS Microbiol Lett. 2011 Jan;314(2):164-9. doi: 10.1111/j.1574-6968.2010.02158.x. Epub 2010 Nov 30. PMID: 21118293.
Additional information: NA
Curation notes: The actual pathway that the MnP enzyme took to degrade AFB1 (aflatoxin B1) was observed through 1H-NMR and HR-ESI-MS analysis. They found that AFB1 is first oxidized to AFB1-8,9-epoxide by MnP and then hydrolyzed to AFB1-8,9-dihydrodiol which is non-toxic and non-carcinogenic.

Source: Abdulla D. Altalhi, Bahig El-Deeb, Localization of zearalenone detoxification gene(s) in pZEA-1 plasmid of Pseudomonas putida ZEA-1 and expressed in Escherichia coli, Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 161, Issues 2–3, 2009, Pages 1166-1172, ISSN 0304-3894, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhazmat.2008.04.068.

Additional information: removed up to 95% within 48 hours. Although degredation by enzymes is the main mechanism for mycotoxin removal, the cell wall also absorbs the patulin
Curation notes: L.casei YZU01 LAB strain used. Only extracellular enzymes degraded patulin. Cell wall of L. casei YZU01 can absorb patulin as another removal method

Source: Kumara SS, Bashisht A, Venkateswaran G, Hariprasad P, Gayathri D. Curation notes: L.fermentum also effective in AFB removal in saline environment

Source: Pizzolitto RP, Salvano MA, Dalcero AM. Analysis of fumonisin B1 removal by microorganisms in co-occurrence with aflatoxin B1 and the nature of the binding process. Int J Food Microbiol. 2012 Jun 1;156(3):214-21. doi: 10.1016/j.ijfoodmicro.2012.03.024. Epub 2012 Mar 28. PMID: 22503712.
Additional information: Fumonisin B1 and AFB1 bind through weak non-covalent bonds to the cell wall and the binding ability of one toxin both not affected by the presence of the other toxin.
Curation notes: S. cerevisiae CECT 1891 strain used.Both removal of FB1 and AFB1 analyzed. No competition for binding sites on cell walls. Presence of one toxin did not change efficiency of removal of the other.

Source: Pizzolitto RP, Salvano MA, Dalcero AM. Analysis of fumonisin B1 removal by microorganisms in co-occurrence with aflatoxin B1 and the nature of the binding process. Int J Food Microbiol. 2012 Jun 1;156(3):214-21. doi: 10.1016/j.ijfoodmicro.2012.03.024. Epub 2012 Mar 28. PMID: 22503712.

Source: Brodehl A, Möller A, Kunte HJ, Koch M, Maul R. Biotransformation of the mycotoxin zearalenone by fungi of the genera Rhizopus and Aspergillus. FEMS Microbiol Lett. 2014 Oct;359(1):124-30.

Source: Wang L, Wu J, Liu Z, Shi Y, Liu J, Xu X, Hao S, Mu P, Deng F, Deng Y. Aflatoxin B1 Degradation and Detoxification by Escherichia coli CG1061 Isolated From Chicken Cecum. Front Pharmacol. 2019 Jan 17;9:1548. doi: 10.3389/fphar.2018.01548. PMID: 30705630; PMCID: PMC6344451.
Environment: Human GI tract, Animal GI tract,
Removal mechanism: biotransformation (AFB1 was bio-transformed to the product C16H14O5 and other metabolites)
Characterization context: live culture (in vivo and in vitro)
Additional information: This strain of E coli is not pathogenic. Extracellular extracts had a much higher rate of degradation compared to intracellular extracts. Degradation rate varied based on heat exposure indicating that the protein responsible is heat-dependent, thus encouraging the prediction that there is an enzyme involved.
Curation notes: Highest degradation activities of E. coli CG1061 appeared at pH 8.5 and 55°C; this may be useful in isolating/identifying the enzyme involved in the biotransformation or for identifying environments where the enzyme would be most effective at degrading AFB1

Source: Juanjuan Song, Shujie Zhang, Yanli Xie, Qian Li, Purification and characteristics of an aflatoxin B1 degradation enzyme isolated from Pseudomonas aeruginosa, FEMS Microbiology Letters, Volume 366, Issue 5, March 2019, fnz034, https://doi.org/10.1093/femsle/fnz034
Environment: soil, water, skin flora, and most man-made environments throughout the world
Additional information: The boil treatment group retained AFB1-degradation activity, which suggested that the active components may be heat-resistent.
Curation notes: Enzyme was identified to be extracellular

Additional information: After incubating the strain, Aflatoxin was still eliminated and the enzyme was shown to be thermostable/heat-resistant
Curation notes: Liquid chromatography mass spectrometry also used as a method to characterize the degradation of AFB1

Source: Righetti, L., Körber, T., Rolli, E. et al. Plant biotransformation of T2 and HT2 toxin in cultured organs of Triticum durum Desf. Sci Rep 9, 14320 (2019). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-50786-w
Additional information: Biotransformation occurs in several organs via glycosylation of T2 and HT2, and acetylation of HT2

Additional information: Biotransformation occurs in several organs via glycosylation of T2 and HT2, and acetylation of HT2
Curation notes: T2 and HT2 absorbed via symplast may encounter enzymes that prevent the toxins from getting into the xylem, by turning them in substances easily segregated in vacuoles or in the apoplast of parenchimatous root cells

Source: Hassan, Y.I., He, J.W., Perilla, N. et al. The enzymatic epimerization of deoxynivalenol by Devosia mutans proceeds through the formation of 3-keto-DON intermediate. Sci Rep 7, 6929 (2017). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-017-07319-0
Additional information: The enzymes that perform biotranformation and their respective mechanisms are not identified, yet it is known that they utilize NADPH and the chemical alterations that they make are known
Curation notes: The epimerization of DON to 3-epi-DON requires NADP(H), indicating the involvement of dehydrogenases/oxidoreductases in the process.

Source: Poppenberger B, Berthiller F, Lucyshyn D, Sieberer T, Schuhmacher R, Krska R, Kuchler K, Glössl J, Luschnig C, Adam G. Detoxification of the Fusarium mycotoxin deoxynivalenol by a UDP-glucosyltransferase from Arabidopsis thaliana. J Biol Chem. 2003 Nov 28;278(48):47905-14. doi: 10.1074/jbc.M307552200. Epub 2003 Sep 11. PMID: 12970342.
Environment: soil, roadside weed. grows in rocky, sandy terrains
Additional information: NA
Curation notes: Arabidopsis thaliana UDP-glucosyltransferase was cloned by functional expression in yeast; allowed phenotypic detection of detoxification activity by simple plate assay

Source: V. Niderkorn,  H. Boudra,  D.P. Morgavi; Binding of Fusarium mycotoxins by fermentative bacteria in vitro.
Additional information: Indicates that binding at the bacterial cell wall is the mechanism of removal of mycotoxins by LAB
Curation notes: I did not see where it said the experiment was conducted under aerobic/anaerobic conditions. Also shares data for fumonisin removal.

Source: H. Bejaoui, F. Mathieu, P. Taillandier, and A. Lebrihi; Conidia of Black Aspergilli as New Biological Adsorbents for Ochratoxin A in Grape Juices and Musts
Additional information: Adsorption phenomenon of OTA on conidia of black aspergilli could be related to hydrophobic interactions
Curation notes: This paper investigates 3 strains with some ability to remove the toxin

Source: H. Bejaoui  F. Mathieu  P. Taillandier, and A. Lebrihi; Ochratoxin A removal in synthetic and natural grape juices by selected oenological Saccharomyces strains
Additional information: Approximately 90% of OTA was bound rapidly within 5 min
Curation notes: S. bayanus was another strain also able to remove Ochratoxin A

Source: Xiaojiao Chang, Hujun Liu, Jing Sun, Jun Wang, Chengcheng Zhao, Wan Zhang, Jie Zhang, and Changpo Sun; Zearalenone Removal from Corn Oil by an Enzymatic Strategy
Additional information: No obvious change in total tocopherols and sterols after enzymatic detoxification was detected when compared with neutralized oil
Curation notes: Can also add that this provides a safe removal with corn oil (not toxic)

Source: Garda-Buffon, Jaqueline, Kupski, Larine, & Badiale-Furlong, Eliana. (2011). Deoxynivalenol (DON) degradation and peroxidase enzyme activity in submerged fermentation. Food Science and Technology, 31(1), 198-203.
Environment: soil(usually from rice soil or rice plants), plants, food
Characterization assay: gas chromatography and flame ionization detector
Additional information: Article also talks about Rhizopus oryzae in addition to the organism I have selected
Curation notes: Typically found in soil from rice or rice plant specifically, paper also dicusses Rhizopus oryzae

Source: DORIS H. D'SOUZA, ROBERT E. BRACKETT; Aflatoxin B1 Degradation by Flavobacterium aurantiacum in the Presence of Reducing Conditions and Seryl and Sulfhydryl Group Inhibitors. J Food Prot 1 February 2001; 64 (2): 268–271.
Environment: soil, water (often freshwater), variety of environments
Enzyme identified?: Unknown -- Enzyme With Seryl, Sulfhydryl Group
Additional information: NA
Curation notes: water environments are typically freshwater, also sulfhydryl enzymes (for reducing toxicity of cadmium)

Source: Guan S, Ji C, Zhou T, Li J, Ma Q, Niu T. Aflatoxin B1 Degradation by Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia and Other Microbes Selected Using Coumarin Medium. International Journal of Molecular Sciences. 2008; 9(8):1489-1503.
Environment: soil, plant, food, animals, aqueous habitats, human skin, hospital environments, and respiratory and GI tracts
Characterization context: live culture with supernatent , liquid culture
Additional information: Study looked at intracellular cell extracts and supernatent. Identification of enzyme is still necessary . Proteinase K, proteinase K plus SDS and heating significantly reduced or eradicated the degradation activity of the culture supernatant.
Curation notes: Also found on surface of human skin, hospital environments, and respiratory and GI tracts. Fluorescence detector used in addition to HPLC.

Source: Zhang, X., Yang, H., Apaliya, M., Zhao, L., Gu, X., Zheng, X., Hu, W. and Zhang, H. (2018), The mechanisms involved in ochratoxin A elimination by Yarrowia lipolytica Y‐2. Ann Appl Biol, 173: 164-174.
Environment: soil, plants, seawater, human lungs, mouth, intestinal tract
Additional information: OTA was degraded to OTα by the hydrolysis activity of carboxypepetidases. studies show that it is not absorption by the cell wall. Many proteins are also invovled in the degradation process.
Curation notes: Yarrowia lipolytica can grow in hydrophobic environments and therefore can metabolize triglycerides and fatty acids for carbon. Paper also claims use of HPLC‐FLD assay.

Source: Varga, J., Péteri, Z., Tábori, K., Téren, J., & Vágvölgyi, C. (2005). Degradation of ochratoxin A and other mycotoxins by rhizopus isolates. International Journal of Food Microbiology, 99(3), 321-328. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijfoodmicro.2004.10.034
Environment: Soil, bread, decaying fruits; moist and warm environments
Additional information: Additional studies are needed to determine specifically which enzymes take part in the detoxification process, and to identify the genes necessary for OTA degradation
Curation notes: Rhizopus isolates were able to degrade more than 95% of ochratoxin A within 16 days

Source: Motomura, M., Toyomasu, T., Mizuno, K., & Shinozawa, T. (2003). Purification and characterization of an aflatoxin degradation enzyme fromPleurotus ostreatus. Microbiological Research, 158(3), 237-242. doi:https://doi.org/10.1078/0944-5013-00199
Additional information: Fluorescence measurements suggest that the enzyme cleaves the lactone ring of AFB1 which normally causes carcinogenic effects
Curation notes: The apparent molecular mass of the purified enzyme was estimated to be 90 kDa by SDS-PAGE. Optimum activities were found in the pH range between 4.0 and 5.0 and at 25°C.

Source: Wang Y, Zhang J, Wang Y, Wang K, Wei H, Shen L. Isolation and characterization of the Bacillus cereus BC7 strain, which is capable of zearalenone removal and intestinal flora modulation in mice. Toxicon. 2018 Dec 1;155:9-20. doi: 10.1016/j.toxicon.2018.09.005. Epub 2018 Sep 26. PMID: 30267721.
Additional information: Further research/determination of the end-metabolite of ZEN would help elucidate the ZEN degradation pathway by B. cereus
Curation notes: Only can remove Zen efficiently in simulated medium of gastric acid. Reduced ZEN degradation at low pHs suggest enzymatic activity

Source: Kosawang C, Karlsson M, Vélëz H, Rasmussen PH, Collinge DB, Jensen B, Jensen DF. Zearalenone detoxification by zearalenone hydrolase is important for the antagonistic ability of Clonostachys rosea against mycotoxigenic Fusarium graminearum. Fungal Biol. 2014 Apr;118(4):364-73. doi: 10.1016/j.funbio.2014.01.005. Epub 2014 Feb 12. PMID: 24742831.
Additional information: NA
Curation notes: Zhd101 was the specific gene isolated for the function of degrading Zearalenone. Knock out mutants of C. rosea (Δzhd101) were unable to detoxify ZEA.

Source: Oswald, Isabelle P., et al. ""Mycotoxin fumonisin B1 increases intestinal colonization by pathogenic Escherichia coli in pigs."" Applied and Environmental Microbiology 69.10 (2003): 5870-5874.
Additional information: FB1 inhibits ceramide synthase activity, which leads to disruption of sphingolipid metabolism
Curation notes: Check on the removal mechanism - the article doesn't mention yeast. Also - Article states that alkaline phosphatase is a measure of FB1 levels, not a biotransformative enzyme

Source: Wall-Martínez HA, Pascari X, Bigordà A, Ramos AJ, Marín S, Sanchis V. The fate of Fusarium mycotoxins (deoxynivalenol and zearalenone) through wort fermenting by Saccharomyces yeasts (S. cerevisiae and S. pastorianus). Food Res Int. 2019 Dec;126:108587. doi: 10.1016/j.foodres.2019.108587. Epub 2019 Jul 29. PMID: 31732066.
Additional information: Contents of yeast cell wall bind to ZEN and 4.5-31.25% was adsorbed, but in wort 31-72% of ZEN was removed.
Curation notes: Important to note that the ZEN toxin was removed in wort between 31 and 72%, and the toxin adsorbed to S.cervisiae  ranged between 4.5 and 31.3%. Shows not all toxin was adsorbed by yeast. Likely extracellular mechanism, but unknown.

Source: Nathanail AV, Gibson B, Han L, Peltonen K, Ollilainen V, Jestoi M, Laitila A. The lager yeast Saccharomyces pastorianus removes and transforms Fusarium trichothecene mycotoxins during fermentation of brewer's wort. Food Chem. 2016 Jul 15;203:448-455. doi: 10.1016/j.foodchem.2016.02.070. Epub 2016 Feb 10. PMID: 26948637.
Removal mechanism: Adsorption and biotransformation during fermentation: further study needed but both seemed to be observed
Enzyme identified?: Possibly Acetyltransferase But Needs More Research
Additional information: analyses of metabolites by LC–QTOF–MS/MS showed mycotoxin conjugates and acetylation was found as the main biotransformation pathway
Curation notes: S. pastorianus is likely an opportunistic pathogen, as it is part of the Saccharomyces genus. Main removal mechanism discussed is adsorbtion. LC–QTOF–MS(/MS) analysis used along with LC–TQ–MS/MS.

Source: Luís Abrunhosa, António Inês, Ana I. Rodrigues, Ana Guimarães, Vânia L. Pereira, Pier Parpot, Arlete Mendes-Faia, Armando Venâncio, Biodegradation of ochratoxin A by Pediococcus parvulus isolated from Douro wines, International Journal of Food Microbiology, Volume 188, 2014, Pages 45-52, ISSN 0168-1605, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijfoodmicro.2014.07.019.
Additional information: They investigate adsorption methods as well, but they were less successful. Strains mediate OTA biodegradation under anaerobic conditions, may be suitable as silage inoculants or as feed additives
Curation notes: strains mediate OTA biodegradation under anaerobic conditions, may be suitable as silage inoculants or as feed additives

Source: Chen SW, Hsu JT, Chou YA, Wang HT. The application of digestive tract lactic acid bacteria with high esterase activity for zearalenone detoxification. J Sci Food Agric. 2018 Aug;98(10):3870-3879. doi: 10.1002/jsfa.8904. Epub 2018 Mar 1. PMID: 29364505.
Environment: animal GI tract, saliva, and food products
Additional information: Observed differences in strains of Lactobacillius plantarums' use of carbon sources, no biotransformants were present and reduction in mycotoxin was by biodegredation. All strains did show binding of toxin to cell wall. Strain B2 had the highest ZEA degrading activity, decreasing ZEA by 52%. All strains showed binding of ZEA to cell wall and biodegredation by esterase
Curation notes: Lactobacillius plantarum is also found in saliva and food products. B2 strain had highest degredation ability while D10 strain showed fast binding, but was released in stationary phase.

Source: Péter Harkai, István Szabó, Mátyás Cserháti, Csilla Krifaton, Anita Risa, Júlia Radó, Adrienn Balázs, Kinga Berta, Balázs Kriszt, Biodegradation of aflatoxin-B1 and zearalenone by Streptomyces sp. collection, International Biodeterioration & Biodegradation, Volume 108, 2016, Pages 48-56, ISSN 0964-8305, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ibiod.2015.12.007.
Additional information: Streptomyces cacaoi subsp. asoensis strain degraded AFB1 over 88% and Streptomyces rimosus almost completely degraded zearalenone. Due to antibiotics production, Streptomyces strains cannot be used in biodegradation methods as a member of inocula but do produce degrading enzymes that could be a promising solution.
Curation notes: Due to antibiotics production, Streptomyces strains cannot be used in biodegradation methods as a member of inocula

Source: Péter Harkai, István Szabó, Mátyás Cserháti, Csilla Krifaton, Anita Risa, Júlia Radó, Adrienn Balázs, Kinga Berta, Balázs Kriszt, Biodegradation of aflatoxin-B1 and zearalenone by Streptomyces sp. collection, International Biodeterioration & Biodegradation, Volume 108, 2016, Pages 48-56, ISSN 0964-8305, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ibiod.2015.12.007.
Additional information: Streptomyces cacaoi subsp. asoensis strain degraded AFB1 over 88% and Streptomyces rimosus almost completely degraded zearalenone. Due to antibiotics production, Streptomyces strains cannot be used in biodegradation methods as a member of inocula but do produce degrading enzymes that could be a promising solution.
Curation notes: Due to antibiotics production, Streptomyces strains cannot be used in biodegradation methods as a member of inocula

Source: Wang Y, Zhang HH, Zhao C, Han YT, Liu YC, Zhang XL. Isolation and characterization of a novel deoxynivalenol-transforming strain Paradevosia shaoguanensis DDB001 from wheat field soil. Lett Appl Microbiol. 2017 Nov;65(5):414-422. doi: 10.1111/lam.12790. Epub 2017 Sep 19. PMID: 28799167.
Additional information: Paradevosia shaoguanensis DDB001 was the specific strain studied, the strain transformed deoxynivalenon into the less toxic form: 3‐epi‐deoxynivalenol (3‐epi‐DON). Can remove 200 mg/L of DON in complete growth medium. Unknown if process is enzymatic and future study is necessary to determine
Curation notes: First study to show that Paradevosia has biotransformation ability. Has no mention if enzymatic/intra/extracellular, future studies still need to be completed.

Source: Zhao, Z., Zhang, Y., Gong, A. et al. Biodegradation of mycotoxin fumonisin B1 by a novel bacterial consortium SAAS79. Appl Microbiol Biotechnol 103, 7129–7140 (2019). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00253-019-09979-6
Additional information: The bacterial consortium came from mushrooms. Pseudomonas was found to be highly responsibile for the mycotoxin degradation. Mechanism is not entirely clear but doth enzyme degradation and adsorption are possible mechanism
Curation notes: Major mechanism of microbial detoxification is attributed to either the adsorption or enzyme action

Source: Hui Tang, Xiaohong Li, Fang Zhang, Xianghong Meng, Bingjie Liu, Biodegradation of the mycotoxin patulin in apple juice by Orotate phosphoribosyltransferase from Rhodotorula mucilaginosa, Food Control, Volume 100, 2019, Pages 158-164, ISSN 0956-7135, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foodcont.2019.01.020.
Additional information: The enzyme was serated from the bacteria and used seperately.  the increase of amino acid concentration may owe to the degradation of Orotate phosphoribosyltransferase.
Curation notes: the increase of amino acid concentration may owe to the degradation of Orotate phosphoribosyltransferase

Source: Danial, EN, Lamfon, MY, Alghamdi, LA, Alamri, AM, Alghamdi, MS, Alghamdi, SA. Remove of aflatoxin G1 using lactic acid bacteria. J Food Process Preserv. 2021; 45:e15090.
Additional information: Experiment compared ten lactic acid bacteria. Mechinism of degradation focused on cell binding.
Curation notes: It seems like the study didn't identify whether the mechanism of degradation was biotransformation or absorption. It only really looked at the binding aspect.

Source: Hideaki KAKEYA, Naoko TAKAHASHI-ANDO, Makoto KIMURA, Rie ONOSE, Isamu YAMAGUCHI, Hiroyuki OSADA, Biotransformation of the Mycotoxin, Zearalenone, to a Non-estrogenic Compound by a Fungal Strain of Clonostachys sp., Bioscience, Biotechnology, and Biochemistry, Volume 66, Issue 12, 1 January 2002, Pages 2723–2726
Additional information: When fed to animals, zearalenone causes serious problems such as vulvovaginitis, constant estrus, pseudopregnancy, infertility, teratogenisity, and mutagenisity
Curation notes: The article suggests that the mechanism is enzymatic as it involves the biotransformation of zearalenone into a less harmful metabolite - enzyme remains unidentified, however

Source: Ragoubi C, Quintieri L, Greco D, Mehrez A, Maatouk I, D'Ascanio V, Landoulsi A, Avantaggiato G. Mycotoxin Removal by Lactobacillus spp. and Their Application in Animal Liquid Feed. Toxins (Basel). 2021 Mar 2;13(3):185. doi: 10.3390/toxins13030185. PMID: 33801544; PMCID: PMC8000088.
Additional information: First study to look at mycotoxin removal in animal liquid feed. Lots of removal mechanisms discussed, most effective in removing ZEA compared to OTA and others. Strain used was CIP 76.13T. Different mediums (PBS or MRS) showed different removal percentages.
Curation notes: There needs to be further research to confirm the removal was by biodegredation but the authors assume it was. No enzyme was identified but likely one involved for degredation.

Source: Wang X, Qin X, Hao Z, Luo H, Yao B, Su X. Degradation of Four Major Mycotoxins by Eight Manganese Peroxidases in Presence of a Dicarboxylic Acid. Toxins (Basel). 2019 Sep 27;11(10):566. doi: 10.3390/toxins11100566. PMID: 31569657; PMCID: PMC6833064.
Additional information: Dicarboxylic acid malonate must be present in order for this enzyme to function. Enyzme was most effective in degrading AFB1. These enzymes were recombinantly produced in E.coli
Curation notes: I. lacteus usually found on rotting wood/logs. Recombinant DNA technology used to transform E. coli to clone and isolate the MnPs. LC-MS/MS used to analyze AFB1 transformation products.

Source: Risa A, Divinyi DM, Baka E, Krifaton C. Aflatoxin B1 detoxification by cell-free extracts of Rhodococcus strains. Acta Microbiol Immunol Hung. 2017 Dec 1;64(4):423-438. doi: 10.1556/030.64.2017.023. Epub 2017 Dec 1. PMID: 29192510.
Additional information: Two Rhodococcus species used R. erythropolis NI1 and R. rhodochrous NI2. 84% degredation potential seen in both strains. Extracellular tested as well, but did not show reduced genotoxicity
Curation notes: used intracellular extracts which showed ability of induced and constitutive enzymes to completely stop genotoxicity of AFB1 within minutes while constitituve enzymes alone took 6 hours, has been a case of bloodstream infection caused by R. erythropolis in immunocompromised male

Source: Wang, Y.; Zhang, H.; Yan, H.; Yin, C.; Liu, Y.; Xu, Q.; Liu, X.; Zhang, Z. Effective Biodegradation of Aflatoxin B1 Using the Bacillus licheniformis (BL010) Strain. Toxins 2018, 10, 497. https://doi.org/10.3390/toxins10120497
Additional information: Strain used was Bacillus licheniformis (BL010). Crude enzyme solution had most degredation. Non induced BL010 did not have degredation capability
Curation notes: B. licheniforms mainly causes infection in immunocompromised but is recognized as a human pathogen. The genes of 2 enzymes, Chia010 and Lac010, likely involved in the biodegredation of AFB1 were found through bioinformatics and the secondary structures were determined through sequence analysis. Futher research of these enzymes is necessary to confirm their role in biodegredation.

Source: Antje Brodehl, Anne Möller, Hans-Jörg Kunte, Matthias Koch, Ronald Maul, Biotransformation of the mycotoxin zearalenone by fungi of the genera Rhizopus and Aspergillus, FEMS Microbiology Letters, Volume 359, Issue 1, October 2014, Pages 124–130
Enzyme identified?: Sulfatase Used To Hydrolyze A Zel-Sulfate Metabolite
Additional information: Two Aspergillus oryzae strains and all seven Rhizopus species were able to convert ZEN into various metabolite
Curation notes: The article seems to indicate that a sulfatase enzyme was used to hydrolyze a ZEL-sulfate metabolite, rather than the zearalenone itself

Source: Na Ge, Jingjing Xu, Bangzhu Peng, Siyi Pan, Adsorption mechanism of tenuazonic acid using inactivated lactic acid bacteria, Food Control, Volume 82, 2017, Pages 274-282, ISSN 0956-7135, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foodcont.2017.07.009.
Environment: dairy, plants, meat, GI of humans/rats
Additional information: modified inactivated lactic acid bacteria used
Curation notes: This bacteria can also be found in meat, mouth and intestines of humans and rats.

Source: Leonardo Petruzzi, Maria Rosaria Corbo, Antonietta Baiano, Luciano Beneduce, Milena Sinigaglia, Antonio Bevilacqua, In vivo stability of the complex ochratoxin A – Saccharomyces cerevisiae starter strains, Food Control, Volume 50, 2015, Pages 516-520, ISSN 0956-7135, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foodcont.2014.09.042.
Environment: fruits, sugar environments, soil, plants, trees, insects, humans
Removal mechanism: Adsorption, Yeast-OTA bound to cell surface
Additional information: S. cerevisiae W13-OTA was most stable to adsorption reversibility
Curation notes: S. cerevisiae is an eukarya and it can also be found in many environents including soil, plants, trees, insects, and humans. Seems like the study doesn't explain a direct mechanism of absorption, but they also mention the binding of yeast-OTA is on the cell surface or hypothesize that it is something on the surface of yeasts.

Source: Arunrussamee Sangsila, Virginie Faucet-Marquis, Annie Pfohl-Leszkowicz, Pariyaporn Itsaranuwat, Detoxification of zearalenone by Lactobacillus pentosus strains, Food Control, Volume 62, 2016, Pages 187-192, ISSN 0956-7135, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.foodcont.2015.10.031.
Additional information: Eight Lactobacillus pentosus strains were used in this experiment
Curation notes: Lactobacillus pentosus fall under the L. plantarum group and they can be found in many places like vegetables, meat, dairy as well as GI tract. Experiment conducted in liquid culture.

Source: Utermark, Jan, and Petr Karlovsky. ""Role of zearalenone lactonase in protection of Gliocladium roseum from fungitoxic effects of the mycotoxin zearalenone."" Applied and environmental microbiology 73.2 (2007): 637-642.
Additional information: The growth of G. roseum was not inhibited by zearalenone, and the lactonase may protect G. roseum from the toxic effects of this mycotoxin
Curation notes: C. roeseum is non-pathogenic to humans, but is a parasite of other fungi and some nematodes
